wiki_catalogs.name: Tool Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on OpenSpec's core value proposition and architectural foundation. Explain how OpenSpec enables spec-driven development for AI coding assistants by aligning human and AI stakeholders through structured change management. Document the fundamental workflow: drafting change proposals, reviewing specifications, implementing tasks, and archiving completed changes. Describe the two-folder model that separates source-of-truth specs (openspec/specs/) from proposed updates (openspec/changes/), enabling clear diff tracking and deterministic outputs. Explain how this approach solves the unpredictability of AI coding assistants when requirements live only in chat history. Cover the key outcomes: agreement on specs before implementation, auditable change tracking, shared visibility into project status, and broad compatibility with existing AI tools. Include practical examples demonstrating the complete workflow from proposal creation to archiving, highlighting how different AI tools interact with OpenSpec through native slash commands or AGENTS.md compatibility. Address the brownfield-first design philosophy that makes OpenSpec particularly effective for modifying existing behavior (1→n) rather than just greenfield development (0→1).

wiki_catalogs.name: Native Integrations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on OpenSpec's native slash command integrations with AI coding assistants. Document the implementation of native support for tools like Claude Code, Cursor, GitHub Copilot, Amazon Q, Cline, Crush, Kilocode, Windsurf, and others through the configurator classes in src/core/configurators/slash/. Explain how each tool-specific configurator (e.g., claude.ts, cursor.ts, github-copilot.ts) extends the base SlashConfigurator and implements the generateSlashCommands method to produce tool-specific command formats. Describe the role of slash-command-templates.ts in defining command structures and placeholders for different AI assistants. Detail how the registry pattern in registry.ts enables automatic discovery and registration of supported tools during 'openspec init'. Provide examples of generated slash commands for various tools and explain how they are written to tool-specific configuration files. Include troubleshooting guidance for common integration issues such as command format mismatches or missing configuration files, and best practices for maintaining consistent command behavior across different AI tools.

wiki_catalogs.name: openspec init
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the openspec init command. Explain its purpose in initializing a new OpenSpec project with AI tool configurations. Document the implementation details in init.ts, including interactive and non-interactive modes, tool selection process, and configuration file generation. Describe how it uses templates from the templates directory to generate project files and integrates with various AI tools through the configurators system. Provide concrete examples of command usage with different options, including the --non-interactive flag and root agents configuration. Explain the relationship between this command and the AGENTS.md file structure. Address common issues such as tool selection errors and configuration file conflicts, along with their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing technical depth on the initialization workflow and template system.

wiki_catalogs.name: Claude Integrations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on OpenSpec's integration with Claude-based AI assistants including Anthropic Claude, Amazon Q, and other Claude-derived tools. Explain how the claude.ts configurator extends the base SlashConfigurator and implements the generateSlashCommands method to produce Claude-specific command formats. Document the use of templates in slash-command-templates.ts for defining Claude's system prompt structure and slash command syntax. Describe how the integration handles context window management, message formatting, and tool-specific constraints. Include practical examples of generated Claude commands and their placement in configuration files. Address common issues such as prompt overflow, command registration failures, and version compatibility between different Claude implementations. Provide best practices for optimizing command effectiveness within Claude's reasoning framework.

wiki_catalogs.name: Installation and Setup
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on OpenSpec installation and project initialization. Detail the prerequisites including Node.js version requirements (≥20.19.0) and package manager options. Document the global installation process using npm with the command 'npm install -g @fission-ai/openspec@latest' and verification steps using 'openspec --version'. Explain the initialization workflow with 'openspec init', including the interactive tool selection process for AI coding assistants with native slash command support. Describe what happens during initialization: creation of the openspec/ directory structure, configuration of slash commands for selected tools, and generation of the managed AGENTS.md file. Cover the optional step of populating project context using openspec/project.md to define tech stack, conventions, and architectural patterns. Include instructions for the Python port alternative using uv/uvx for users who prefer Python. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues such as slash commands not appearing (requiring AI tool restart) and permission errors during global installation. Document the post-setup verification process using 'openspec list' to confirm proper configuration.

wiki_catalogs.name: AGENTS.md Compatibility
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on OpenSpec's AGENTS.md compatibility system. Explain how this standardized instruction file enables cross-tool compatibility for AI assistants like Amp, Jules, and other tools that don't support native slash commands. Document the structure of AGENTS.md, including the managed <!-- OPENSPEC:START --> to <!-- OPENSPEC:END --> block that contains project-specific instructions. Describe how the AgentsConfigurator in agents.ts generates and updates this file during 'openspec init' and 'openspec update' operations. Detail the template system in agents-template.ts that populates the instruction content with project context and change management guidelines. Explain how AI assistants should be configured to automatically load AGENTS.md when handling requests related to proposals, specs, or architectural changes. Provide examples of instruction content and explain how team members can ensure all assistants have access to current project guidelines regardless of their preferred tool. Include troubleshooting guidance for issues like stale instructions or missing file references.

wiki_catalogs.name: openspec update
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the openspec update command. Explain its purpose in refreshing AI tool configuration files when project settings change. Document the implementation details in update.ts, including how it detects existing configurations and applies updates while preserving custom modifications. Describe the integration with the configurators registry and how it handles multiple AI tools. Provide examples of typical update scenarios, such as adding new slash commands or modifying existing tool configurations. Explain the relationship between this command and the initialization process. Address common issues like merge conflicts during updates and tool-specific configuration problems, along with their solutions. Include information about the command's role in maintaining synchronization between project settings and AI tool instructions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Cursor Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on OpenSpec's integration with Cursor AI. Explain how the cursor.ts configurator implements the SlashConfigurator interface to generate Cursor-specific slash commands. Document the structure of Cursor's command format as defined in slash-command-templates.ts, including special handling for Cursor's project-wide search and edit capabilities. Describe how OpenSpec's integration enables seamless specification-driven development within Cursor's IDE environment. Provide examples of generated commands for common workflows like change implementation and validation. Address troubleshooting steps for common issues such as command registration failures, incorrect template rendering, and synchronization problems between OpenSpec changes and Cursor's workspace. Include configuration best practices for maximizing Cursor's AI capabilities through OpenSpec.

wiki_catalogs.name: Command Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on OpenSpec's command-line interface. Document all available commands and their primary functions, serving as a quick reference for developers. Include 'openspec init' for project setup, 'openspec update' for refreshing AI tool configurations, 'openspec list' for viewing active changes, 'openspec view' for the interactive dashboard, 'openspec archive' for completing changes, 'openspec validate' for specification checking, 'openspec show' for change details, and 'openspec change' for managing change operations. For each command, provide the basic syntax, primary use case, and relationship to the overall workflow. Explain how these commands map to the core functionality implemented in the src/core and src/commands directories. Include examples of common command sequences that represent typical user workflows, such as initializing a project followed by listing changes. Address how the Commander.js framework structures the CLI interface and routes commands to their respective handlers. Document the global nature of the installation and how the executable is made available in the system path.

wiki_catalogs.name: openspec list
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the openspec list command. Explain its purpose in displaying active changes and their progress status. Document the implementation details in list.ts, including how it discovers change directories, parses proposal files, and calculates completion metrics. Describe the integration with the change parser that extracts tasks and their status from specification files. Provide examples of output formats and filtering options. Explain how the command supports the change management workflow by providing visibility into ongoing work. Address common issues such as parsing errors in change files and incorrect progress calculations, along with their solutions. Include information about sorting behavior and how changes are prioritized in the output.

wiki_catalogs.name: GitHub Copilot Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on OpenSpec's integration with GitHub Copilot. Explain how the github-copilot.ts configurator extends the base SlashConfigurator to generate Copilot-specific commands compatible with GitHub's AI assistant ecosystem. Document the template structure in slash-command-templates.ts for Copilot's command syntax and context requirements. Describe how the integration leverages Copilot's codebase awareness and suggestion capabilities within the OpenSpec workflow. Provide examples of generated commands for specification implementation and change validation. Address common integration challenges such as authentication requirements, command scope limitations, and version compatibility between OpenSpec and Copilot's evolving API. Include best practices for structuring specifications to maximize Copilot's effectiveness and maintain security compliance.

wiki_catalogs.name: AI Tool Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on OpenSpec's integration with various AI coding assistants. Document the two integration approaches: native slash command support for tools like Claude Code, Cursor, and GitHub Copilot, and AGENTS.md compatibility for tools like Amp and Jules. List all supported tools and their specific command formats and configuration file locations. Explain how the configurator registry pattern in src/core/configurators enables extensibility and dynamic discovery of tool integrations. Describe the template system that generates configuration files based on project context, including slash command templates and agent instruction templates. Detail how 'openspec init' prompts users to select tools with native support while ensuring all assistants can access instructions through the managed AGENTS.md file. Explain the role of 'openspec update' in refreshing agent instructions when team members switch tools. Provide implementation details from the configurator classes (claude.ts, cursor.ts, github-copilot.ts, etc.) and template files that handle tool-specific formatting requirements. Include troubleshooting guidance for integration issues and best practices for maintaining compatibility across different AI tools.

wiki_catalogs.name: openspec view
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the openspec view command. Explain its purpose as an interactive dashboard for navigating project changes and specifications. Document the implementation details in view.ts, including the use of Inquirer for interactive prompts and ORA for loading indicators. Describe the hierarchical navigation system that allows users to browse changes, view specifications, and access validation results. Provide examples of user interactions and navigation patterns. Explain how this command enhances developer experience by providing a visual interface to the specification-driven workflow. Address common issues such as terminal compatibility problems and navigation errors, along with their solutions. Include information about the command's role in change discovery and status monitoring.

wiki_catalogs.name: Other Assistant Integrations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on OpenSpec's integration with alternative AI coding assistants including Cline, Crush, Kilocode, Windsurf, and Factory AI. Explain how each tool-specific configurator (cline.ts, crush.ts, etc.) implements the SlashConfigurator interface to generate assistant-specific command formats. Document the common patterns and tool-specific variations in command structure as defined in slash-command-templates.ts. Describe how the registry pattern enables automatic discovery of these integrations during project initialization. Provide comparative examples of generated commands across different assistants and their respective configuration file placements. Address troubleshooting guidance for common cross-platform issues such as inconsistent command behavior, template rendering errors, and compatibility problems with evolving assistant APIs. Include best practices for maintaining consistent development workflows across multiple AI assistant platforms.

wiki_catalogs.name: Specification Format
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on OpenSpec's specification format and conventions. Detail the structured markdown format used for requirements and scenarios, including the use of '### Requirement:' headers and '#### Scenario:' blocks with Gherkin-style WHEN/THEN syntax. Explain the delta format used in change proposals with '## ADDED Requirements', '## MODIFIED Requirements', and '## REMOVED Requirements' sections that represent patches to the existing specifications. Document the validation rules enforced by the system, including the requirement for every specification to have at least one scenario and the use of SHALL/MUST terminology in requirement text. Describe how the markdown parser in src/core/parsers/markdown-parser.ts processes these files and extracts structured data. Explain the relationship between the current truth in openspec/specs/ and proposed updates in openspec/changes/. Provide examples of well-formed specifications and common formatting errors. Include guidance on organizing specifications into subdirectories by feature area and maintaining living documentation through the archiving process.

wiki_catalogs.name: openspec archive
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the openspec archive command. Explain its purpose in finalizing completed changes by moving them to the archive directory. Document the implementation details in archive.ts, including change validation before archiving, directory relocation, and optional specification preservation. Describe how it integrates with AI tool configurations by removing obsolete slash commands and updating instruction files. Provide examples of command usage with different flags, such as --keep-specs. Explain the relationship between archiving and the overall change management lifecycle. Address common issues like archiving incomplete changes and file permission errors, along with their solutions. Include information about the command's role in maintaining a clean working directory and project history.

wiki_catalogs.name: Change Management Workflow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on OpenSpec's change management lifecycle. Document the complete workflow from proposal creation to archiving, including drafting change proposals, reviewing and refining specifications, implementing tasks, and completing changes. Explain the directory structure of change folders in openspec/changes/ that contain proposal.md, tasks.md, and spec deltas. Describe how AI assistants create and manage these files based on natural language requests or slash commands. Detail the archiving process that merges approved updates from change proposals into the source-of-truth specifications in openspec/specs/. Explain how the change parser processes proposal files and how the archive command handles the merge operation. Cover the use of tasks.md for implementation checklists with markdown checkboxes that AI assistants can update as they complete work. Include best practices for writing effective change proposals and managing multiple concurrent changes. Address how the system maintains auditability and explicit scope throughout the development process.

wiki_catalogs.name: openspec validate
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the openspec validate command. Explain its purpose in verifying the correctness and completeness of specification files. Document the implementation details in validate.ts and validator.ts, including schema validation using Zod, requirement checking, and error message generation. Describe the different validation modes (standard and enriched output) and their use cases. Provide examples of validation output for both successful and failed cases, including common error types. Explain how validation integrates with the specification format and enforces OpenSpec conventions. Address common issues such as cryptic error messages and false positives, along with their solutions. Include information about performance considerations when validating large numbers of specifications.

wiki_catalogs.name: Interactive Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on OpenSpec's interactive capabilities. Document the TTY-based interactive mode that uses Inquirer for user prompts during key operations like 'openspec init' and 'openspec archive'. Explain how the interactive utilities in src/utils/interactive.ts provide a consistent user experience across different commands. Detail the interactive selection process for AI tools during project initialization, including both interactive and non-interactive modes. Describe the confirmation prompts during archiving operations and how users can bypass them with the --yes flag. Cover the interactive dashboard feature accessible through 'openspec view' that provides visual feedback on project status. Explain the technical implementation using the @inquirer/prompts library and how interactive components are integrated with the core command logic. Provide examples of interactive workflows and guidance on when to use interactive versus non-interactive modes in different environments (local development vs. CI/CD pipelines).

wiki_catalogs.name: openspec show
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the openspec show command. Explain its purpose in displaying detailed information about specific changes or specifications. Document the implementation details in show.ts, including change discovery, content parsing, and formatted output generation. Describe how it handles different input types (change IDs, specification paths) and provides context-aware information. Provide examples of output formats for various use cases, such as showing change proposals versus specification details. Explain how this command supports debugging and review workflows by providing focused information. Address common issues such as invalid change identifiers and parsing errors, along with their solutions. Include information about integration with the interactive mode for enhanced navigation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Validation System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on OpenSpec's specification validation system. Document the validation rules that ensure specifications adhere to the required format, including proper header structure, requirement-scenario relationships, and delta syntax. Explain how the Zod-based schema validation in src/core/schemas/base.schema.ts enforces data integrity and the validator implementation in src/core/validation/validator.ts processes markdown files. Describe the different validation modes and error reporting, including enriched error messages that help users quickly identify and fix issues. Cover the integration between the validation command and the core validation logic, showing how 'openspec validate' provides feedback on specification quality. Detail the scope-aware validation that considers the context of changes and how validation fits into the overall development workflow as a quality gate before implementation. Provide examples of common validation errors and their solutions, along with best practices for writing easily validatable specifications. Address how validation contributes to the predictability and reliability of AI-generated code.

wiki_catalogs.name: openspec change
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the openspec change command. Explain its purpose in managing change operations, including creating new changes and modifying existing ones. Document the implementation details in change.ts, including interactive mode for change creation, task management, and integration with the specification system. Describe how it handles change lifecycle operations beyond simple creation, such as status updates and task tracking. Provide examples of command usage for creating changes with different templates and modifying existing change metadata. Explain the relationship between this command and the changes directory structure. Address common issues such as naming conflicts and invalid change states, along with their solutions. Include information about bulk operations and interactive selection features.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration Files
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on OpenSpec's configuration files and project structure. Document the purpose and format of AGENTS.md as the standardized hand-off file for AI coding assistants, explaining how it contains workflow instructions that tools automatically read. Describe openspec/project.md as the project-level context file for defining tech stack, architectural patterns, and development conventions that should be followed across all changes. Explain the directory structure of the openspec/ folder including the separation between specs/ (current truth) and changes/ (proposed updates). Detail how configuration files are generated during 'openspec init' and updated during 'openspec update'. Cover the role of these files in maintaining consistency across team members using different AI tools. Provide guidance on maintaining and evolving these configuration files as projects grow. Include examples of well-structured project.md files that effectively communicate important context to AI assistants.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis of OpenSpec

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
OpenSpec is an AI-native system designed for specification-driven development, enabling developers to manage AI-assisted workflows through structured specifications and change proposals. The system bridges human developers and AI coding assistants by providing standardized instruction formats and validation mechanisms.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Provide a standardized framework for AI-assisted development workflows
- Enable structured specification and change management processes
- Support multiple AI coding tools through unified configuration and integration
- Facilitate validation and verification of AI-generated code changes
- Create a transparent, auditable development process for AI-assisted programming

### Target Audience
The primary users of OpenSpec are software development teams and individual developers who leverage AI coding assistants (such as GitHub Copilot, Claude Code, Cursor, etc.) in their workflow. It's particularly valuable for teams seeking to standardize AI interactions, maintain code quality, and implement governance in AI-assisted development environments.

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
OpenSpec follows a modular architecture with clear separation between CLI interface, core functionality, and utility components. The system is built with TypeScript and follows a command-based pattern for extensibility.

### Design Patterns
The project implements several key design patterns:
- **Command Pattern**: Each CLI operation is encapsulated in a dedicated command class
- **Registry Pattern**: Tool configurators are managed through registry classes for dynamic discovery
- **Template Pattern**: Configuration files are generated from templates with project context
- **Dependency Injection**: Core components are injected into commands rather than being directly imported

### System Relationships
```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[CLI Interface] --> B[Command Handlers]
    B --> C[Core Services]
    C --> D[Configurators]
    C --> E[Parsers]
    C --> F[Validators]
    C --> G[Templates]
    D --> H[AI Tools]
    E --> I[Specification Files]
    F --> J[Validation Rules]
    G --> K[Project Structure]
```

### Data Flow
```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[User Input] --> B[CLI Parser]
    B --> C[Command Execution]
    C --> D[File System]
    D --> E[Read Configuration]
    D --> F[Read Specifications]
    C --> G[Process Data]
    G --> H[Generate Output]
    H --> I[Update Files]
    I --> J[Display Results]
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- [index.ts](src/cli/index.ts): Primary CLI entry point that defines all commands and options
- [openspec.js](bin/openspec.js): Executable script that bootstraps the CLI application

### Core Modules
- [init.ts](src/core/init.ts): Handles project initialization and AI tool configuration
- [update.ts](src/core/update.ts): Manages updates to AI tool instruction files
- [config.ts](src/core/config.ts): Central configuration management and AI tool definitions
- [list.ts](src/core/list.ts): Implements listing functionality for changes and specifications

### Configuration Approach
- [config.ts](src/core/config.ts): Defines constants and configuration interfaces
- [package.json](package.json): Specifies project metadata, dependencies, and scripts
- [pyproject.toml](python_port/pyproject.toml): Configuration for Python port

### External Dependencies
- [package.json](package.json): Lists npm dependencies including commander, inquirer, chalk, ora, and zod
- [pyproject.toml](python_port/pyproject.toml): Lists Python dependencies for the Python port

### Integration Points
- [configurators](src/core/configurators): Integration with various AI tools (Claude, Cursor, GitHub Copilot, etc.)
- [slash](src/core/configurators/slash): Specialized integration for slash commands in AI tools
- [templates](src/core/templates): Template system for generating configuration files

### Component Relationships
```mermaid
graph LR
    CLI[CLI Interface] --> Init[Init Command]
    CLI --> Update[Update Command]
    CLI --> List[List Command]
    CLI --> Archive[Archive Command]
    CLI --> Validate[Validate Command]
    Init --> Configurators[Tool Configurators]
    Update --> Configurators
    Init --> Templates[Templates]
    Configurators --> AI_Tools[AI Tools]
    Templates --> File_System[File System]
    Configurators --> File_System
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
OpenSpec provides a comprehensive suite of features for managing AI-assisted development:

1. **Project Initialization**: Sets up the OpenSpec structure and configures AI tools
2. **Tool Configuration**: Integrates with multiple AI coding assistants through custom configurations
3. **Change Management**: Tracks feature proposals and implementation progress
4. **Specification Management**: Maintains structured specifications for project components
5. **Validation System**: Validates both changes and specifications for completeness
6. **Interactive Dashboard**: Provides visibility into project status and progress

### Implementation Highlights
- [init.ts](src/core/init.ts): Implements interactive wizard for tool selection and configuration
- [update.ts](src/core/update.ts): Handles updating existing AI tool configurations
- [list.ts](src/core/list.ts): Provides listing functionality for both changes and specifications
- [config.ts](src/core/config.ts): Centralizes AI tool definitions and configuration constants

### Feature Architecture
```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> Initialize: openspec init
    Initialize --> Configure_Tools: Select AI tools
    Configure_Tools --> Setup_Complete: Generate configurations
    
    Idle --> Update: openspec update
    Update --> Refresh_Configs: Update AI instructions
    Refresh_Configs --> Update_Complete: Show summary
    
    Idle --> List: openspec list
    List --> Display_Items: Show changes/specs
    Display_Items --> Idle
    
    Idle --> Validate: openspec validate
    Validate --> Check_Items: Validate changes/specs
    Check_Items --> Report_Results: Show validation output
    Report_Results --> Idle
    
    Idle --> Archive: openspec archive
    Archive --> Process_Change: Archive completed change
    Process_Change --> Update_Specs: Update main specifications
    Update_Specs --> Archive_Complete: Confirm completion
```
</blog>
